B000BW7QWW|5.0|Sci-Fi, Western, drama, comedy, action-adventure, space opera, whatever you want to call it, this film is all heart.  The characters are quickly outlined and filled in, brought to life in their interactions with each other and the breakneck pace of the plot.  If it feels a bit rushed compared to most films, that is only because this movie has so much more to say.  This movie is not about space, politics, or good and evil, it is about people.  An unusually large cast of \\"main characters\\" is quickly and adeptly introduced to you, each of which is endearing in their own peculiar way.  A doctor with endless devotion to his sister, a mechanic with an unstoppable sunny disposition, a quirky and somewhat goofy pilot, a caring and wise religious man, a mildly dimwitted yet powerful mercenary, the doctor's tortured and talented young sister, an unfailingly loyal first mate, a stunning and adoring companion, and the rugged realist who captains them all in their attempts to carve out a life for themselves on the edge of civilization. <br /> <br />The companion is actually a prostitute, and yet somehow she is the only character with any real social status and respectability in society.  And it doesn't bother you or seem quaint.  In the amazing world that has been created here, it just seems normal. <br /> <br />That being said, so interested in every aspect of the \\"verse\\" due to brilliant and witty dialogue sprinkled over a deep and involving plot, I could have easily sat for another two hours if they had chosen to dig deeper into this world.  I swear I thought the whole thing lasted only 40 minutes.  The world Mr. Whedon has created is teeming with depth and completeness that draws you in quickly, and seems tangible from the first scene. <br /> <br />As the plot unfolds and the action sets in, the interactions between the characters are engaging and brief, but much like old friends you haven't seen in awhile, you immediately understand where they are coming from and the intricacies and depths of their relationships to each other.  These relationships serve not only to illustrate the story and decisions they face, but they actually drive it forward and add great depth to the conflicts unfolding on screen.  As varied a crew as they are, they seem at home with each other and so real you'd think you might run into them at the shopping mall or grocery store. <br /> <br />There is a heartfelt sincerity and love that is exuding from the experience of this film, and I consider myself lucky to have caught it at the end of its run in the theatres.  On a Sunday afternoon, with a rather old crowd and about a half-full theatre, the audience actually stood up and applauded this film when it finished.  A sixty year old woman walked out with tears in her eyes, and I myself actually had trouble driving all the way home, so many thoughts about family and friends were racing through my head. <br /> <br />This film is all heart.  If you have a heart, you should buy it.

In any case, here's a true, valid review of this album: It's musically amazing, but the rating has to be slightly downgraded because of its lyrics in some songs. \\"I Love New York\\" is hard to listen to because it's Madonna trying so hard to be something she's not. However, she completely makes up for it with musical masterpieces, such as \\"Sorry\\" and \\"Jump\\" which are riveting and live in your head long after the songs stop playing. \\"Isaac\\" is not the controversial track it was made out to be. B000AA305M|2.0|What you should know right off the bat is that David Gray's newest album doesn't use the same recording environment as... well, pretty much the rest of his catalog. Instead of holing up in a basement or attic with a Midi sequencer and a weathered guitar, Gray has gone hi-fi, with the occasional (mostly) subtle string accompaniment. I'm convinced that Gray is strongest when *just* using a guitar or keyboard, but he doesn't seem to want that attention. But at least this new producer apparently got Gray to stay away from the Midi sequencer, the root of the drum and bass flourishes that distracts from some of his finest work, in my humble opinion.<br /><br />The first track, \\"Alibi,\\" is practically a template for the rest of the album, for better or worse. It ambles along with some spare mid-tempo minor keys before it finally crashes into a chorus that sounds fantastic with headphones but is otherwise not worth the wait. You'll find the theme of \\"not enough seasoning in the soup\\" throughout this album, in my opinion. Some brilliant things occasionally shine through, but Gray is otherwise far too sedate and relaxed.<br /><br />\\"The One I Love\\" goes Bryan Adams (not *Ryan* Adams) on us, with twangy roots rock, but it too doesn't do anything of distinction until about halfway through, before quickly running back to safe territory.<br /><br />The unusual time signature of \\"Lately\\" isn't too jarring when the percussion and drums finally come in, and at least the man is at last streching some creative wings. The lyrics, unfortunately, tread water, with the chorus in 4:4 time to reinforce the generally conventioal direction of the album. It also overstays its welcome by a good minute.<br /><br />\\"Nos Da Cariad\\" is where things warm up. In fact, up until this point I'd never heard the man rock harder. Syncopated, off-beat percussion definitely helps this track, as do the sinuously-delivered lyrics. Some backup female vocalists (!) come in about halfway through, but Gray doesn't give us much more than a tease. Then he pulls back with a breakdown and gradually adds all the layers back into a climactic end. Catchy overall, but it doesn't stand up to extensive repeats.<br /><br />\\"Slow Motion\\" does, however. The heavy drums harken back cringingly to his electro-stained earlier work (I say \\"stained\\" because I thought the combination was horrible), but once again, halfway through, he throws a delightful curveball with a upbeat chanting chorus, followed by a gentle breakdown and another buildup to that really chatchy chorus. It's an infectiously happy song.<br /><br />\\"From Here...\\" sounds like a sketch, not a completely filled out song. It's so sparse and unmodulated that it never really takes off, although it suggests it might at any moment. I dislike that kind of musical tension if there's no payoff. His falsetto is quite awesome here, but underused.<br /><br />\\"Ain't No Love\\" is a gem, although I would like to know what it is, since it's not love. He mentions it several times but never finishes the thought. Gray starts out with what sounds like a clavier before sliding gently into a soulful piano ballad. His raspy voice is used to particularly good effect here. The middle section gets uncomfortably late-period Foreigner before settling for returning to the opening verses, thus (in my opinion) lessening their impact.<br /><br />\\"Hospital Food,\\" besides being a whiplash change of pace from the track right before it, has some odd Southern rock harmonizing on the  vocals (odd for Gray, anyway) but otherwise sounds, honestly, like an alt country toss-off. He seems barely interested, and the song doesn't end so much as deflate ungracefully.<br /><br />\\"Now and Always\\" was such a formulaic yet bloated effort that I could barely sit through my only complete listen. It barely registers on the album's radar. He has a Beatles-esque crescdendo at the end, but it's yet another case of taking too long to deliver too little.<br /><br />\\"Disappearing World\\"(misspelled on the album) is also quite staid, save for a eye-widening rock-out (almost precisely in the middle of the song) that sounds like a snippet from a much more energetic album -- performed, arranged and produced by other people. Yet, once again, he retreats to a quiet and undistinguished resolution.<br /><br />...So it's a little bitter that David Gray took so long to realize he could record in an infinitely superior production environment, because he only shows glimmers of that same downtrodden, rained-on passion and soulfulness that allowed his earlier work to overcome its low fidelity and narrow instrumental scope. After all, he *has* been pushing out material on a regular basis for over ten years now, with nine or so main releases.  That's a helluva lot of tracks to press.<br /><br />But he also apparently isn't downtrodden anymore. While his success gets him production values that bring him closer to Billy Joel-like piano rock (which sounds like his calling at this point), it also seems to have assuaged him of the pains that he strummed about before. In his previous work, I thought that Gray was often engrossingly analyzing the human condition, but I guess  he was only lamenting *his* condition, which the eventual royalty checks and public affection cured him of.<br /><br />So what now for us miserable bastards, now that one of our mascots hit the jackpot and found his personal Jesus in the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow? I have a strong feeling that his songs are going to start showing up in car commercials and forgettable, big-budget relationship chick flicks like \\"Serendipity\\" and \\"Autumn in New York.\\" Gah.<br /><br />I hate to say it, but this album is a pretty good explanation of why David Gray isn't a household name. He really could have grabbed the bull by the horns, but seems like he doesn't have the passion for the chase. There's also much less of the insightful and poignant lyrics that make songs like \\"Hello and Goodbye\\" and \\"Lead Me Upstairs\\" nearly indelible. He ends up using refrains a lot instead.<br /><br />You'll probably disagree with me, until you've given your favorite songs some extensive listening and discovered that there usually isn't much to recommend to them aside from a brief splash of energy and superior production. The more I listen to this album, the more I enjoy his more lyrically rewarding work. \\"Slow Motion,\\" in my opinion, is the only true keeper. Too much of the remainder is David Gray doing an unconvincing job of heartbroken minstrel.<br /><br />On the other hand, he has an album of re-recorded material on iTunes that strips out a lot of the bassy drumminess of his earlier stuff and allows me to enjoy his best material as I personally think it was meant to be heard: with a piano or a guitar. Artistically, it's a little saddening to hear how much more soulfulness he pours out on the iTunes stuff -- his earlier work. It just reinforces the rote aftertaste of almost everything on Life in Slow Motion.\\"Disappearing World\\" (misspelled on the album) is also quite staid, save for a eye-widening rock-out (almost precisely in the middle of the song) that sounds like a snippet from a much more energetic album -- performed, arranged and produced by other people. Yet, once again, he retreats to a quiet and undistinguished resolution. <br /> <br />...So it's a little bitter that David Gray took so long to realize he could record in an infinitely superior production environment, because he only shows glimmers of that same downtrodden, rained-on passion and soulfulness that allowed his earlier work to overcome its low fidelity and narrow instrumental scope. After all, he *has* been pushing out material on a regular basis for over ten years now, with nine or so main releases.  That's a helluva lot of tracks to press. <br /> <br />But he also apparently isn't downtrodden anymore. While his success gets him production values that bring him closer to Billy Joel-like piano rock (which sounds like his calling at this point), it also seems to have assuaged him of the pains that he strummed about before. In his previous work, I thought that Gray was often engrossingly analyzing the human condition, but I guess  he was only lamenting *his* condition, which the eventual royalty checks and public affection cured him of. <br /> <br />So what now for us miserable bastards, now that one of our mascots hit the jackpot and found his personal Jesus in the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow? I have a strong feeling that his songs are going to start showing up in car commercials and forgettable, big-budget relationship chick flicks like \\"Serendipity\\" and \\"Autumn in New York.\\" Gah. <br /> <br />I hate to say it, but this album is a pretty good explanation of why David Gray isn't a household name. He really could have grabbed the bull by the horns, but seems like he doesn't have the passion for the chase. There's also much less of the insightful and poignant lyrics that make songs like \\"Hello and Goodbye\\" and \\"Lead Me Upstairs\\" nearly indelible. He ends up using refrains a lot instead. <br /> <br />You'll probably disagree with me, until you've given your favorite songs some extensive listening and discovered that there usually isn't much to recommend to them aside from a brief splash of energy and superior production. The more I listen to this album, the more I enjoy his more lyrically rewarding work. \\"Slow Motion,\\" in my opinion, is the only true keeper. Too much of the remainder is David Gray doing an unconvincing job of heartbroken minstrel. <br /> <br />On the other hand, he has an album of re-recorded material on iTunes that strips out a lot of the bassy drumminess of his earlier stuff and allows me to enjoy his best material as I personally think it was meant to be heard: with a piano or a guitar. Artistically, it's a little saddening to hear how much more soulfulness he pours out on the iTunes stuff -- his earlier work. It just reinforces the rote aftertaste of almost everything on Life in Slow Motion.

0140177396|5.0|\\"Of Mice and Men\\" is an absolutely stirring, poignant, and tragic portrait of human nature, a book of harsh reality. As a book of only 107 pages, many find it hard to believe that such a short book can have such impact on the reader, in dealing with such a complex subject. This is great testament to the author, John Steinbeck, and his short, sweet, and to-the-point writing style, letting the characters provide the complexity (there is a LOT of dialogue) through their interaction. Ranch laborers Lennie and George both seek a real, yet delusional dream, that they want to believe is tangible, but the reality is very different, as others have dreamt it before them, while they at the same time have done absolutely nothing towards the dream's realization. It is all just an illusion, by those who seek to transcend their current situation in life, just keeping the dream with them, for whenever they need it, for their personal reassurance that one day, things will change.  It is worth reading for the last 8 pages alone, for its stirring, disturbing, and tragically humanistic climax. Definitely one of the best fictions I've ever read. Highly recommended, unless you're one of those who got the book banned from several school libraries in 1993 and 1994 for \\"promoting euthanasia\\".................................

B000002QWD|5.0|Since the song \\"White Christmas\\" is the most popular Christmas song and that song is so closely associated with Bing Crosby, well, you simply need this disk to play and fill your home with music for the Season.  Those of you who do not remember or even know of Bing Crosby can search the Web and find out what a huge star he was in the thirties and forties.  He continued through the fifties and sixties, but more limited to his generation, like those older rock acts you see on PBS nowadays.<br /><br />Anyway, he does the songs in his own way, but very straight by today's standards.  The mood he captures is how Christmas felt around my house when I was a child.  Heck, he even sings a verse of Adeste Fidelis (O Come, All Ye Faithful) in Latin (albeit a twangy American Latin - just the kind that would have been heard in a Catholic church at the time).  There are a couple of upbeat novelty Christmas songs such as \\"Christmas in Killarney\\" and \\"Mele Kalikimaka\\" (Merry Christmas in Hawaiian - very popular and exotic at the time).  He does three of the numbers with the Andrews sisters (including a delightful swing \\"Jingle Bells\\") and \\"Silver Bells\\" with Carole Richards.<br /><br />Fine Christmas album.  It just can't be a complete Christmas without Der Bingle singing \\"White Christmas\\", would it?

B000089RV6|5.0|I own over a 1000 cds but there are only a handful of albums where I think every track is great. This is one of those albums! Even 25 years after the release of Back In Black I still listen to it at least once a month. Songs like Hells Bells and Have A Drink On Me still get my blood pumping. After the unfortunate death of charismatic lead singer Bon Scott, AC/DC came back stronger than ever. Enter ex-Geordie vocalist Brian Johnson and the band would create a classic album that would go on to sell more than 21 million copies in the US alone! Apparently Bon had all the lyrics written for this follow-up to the excellent Highway To Hell, but when Brian joined he decided to re-write them. I don't think Brian's sense of humor is quite as clever as Bon's but there are plenty of classic lyrics all over Back In Black and Brian has quite a set of pipes. It would have been interesting to hear Bon sing these songs but maybe it was his death that pushed the band to another level. The production and songwriting on Back In Black are the highest level the band ever achieved. Angus' lead guitar is simply the best of his career. Check out the solos to Hells Bells, Shake A Leg, and the title track! And the riffs are some of the catchiest that the Young brother's ever came up with. I'm not going to bother going into each track because they all rock. Back In Black is an album that everyone should own!!

B0007TKNL0|5.0|The latest adaptation of \\"The Phantom Of The Opera\\" was quite different from what I expected.  My only experience with musicals outside of Disney material like \\"Cinderella\\" and \\"Beauty And The Beast\\" (both recommended) comes from \\"The Sound Of Music\\" and \\"The Wizard Of Oz\\" (also both recommended), and for some reason I expected this version of \\"Phantom\\" to be full of lavish sets and singing during the rehearsals and performances of the stage company's productions (which it was) but I didn't expect so much of the film outside of those parts to be conducted in song.  At first it discombulated me a bit, but as the movie went on I was increasingly glad it had taken this route.  It was an unusual way to go for what, while being a romantic movie lush with tragedy, is still also very much a horror movie.  But the songs and musical accompaniment all through - expertly done by an extremely talented cast and ensemble of musicians - perfectly conveyed what the movie was going for. <br /> <br />   Full of grandeur, dark awe, emotion and visual magnificence, the latest version of the tale of the ill-fortuned opera house and its resident specter combs territory not fully delved into in previous versions I've seen and features cinematography that develops the most dramatic moments to maximum effectiveness.  The amount of light-hearted humor was also unexpected, but it made for some great contrasts, including the first appearance of the thunderous-voiced Phantom during a packed-house performance of one of the company's musicals, bringing the house to a shocking standstill. <br /> <br />  One of the few problems was with the Phantom's main nemesis.  He was a fine, likable character, the performer who portrayed him a great actor and a great singer, but he did not strike me as being a realistically adequate foil for the grand and often ferocious Phantom.  A defeciency that's not crippling but has slightly hobbled a few excellent horror movies over the years.   <br /> <br />The otherversions of the \\"Phantom\\" movie I've seen are the Hammer version starring Herbert Lom and Heather Sears - not one of the best Hammer movies by a long shot, but still good, featuring an excellent turn by Michael Gough as the wickedly and humourously deplorable theater owner: it's available in the \\"Hammer Horror Series\\" set which also includes alltime greats like \\"Nightmare\\" and \\"Night Creatures\\"; and the 1989 Robert Englund/Jill Schoelen version - a much more vicious version feauring a far less sympathetic Phantom, it also has some great music that's sadly gone unnoticed. <br /> <br />All 3 versions recommended; I've yet to see the Lon Chaney silent version, the 40s Universal version, the 1998 \\"Il Fantasma Dell'Opera\\" Italian-language version, the 1916 German silent version (apparantly among a number of films from that era of which no print exists any longer, sadly), or the 1983 or 1990 made-for-tv versions. <br /> <br />

0767802470|4.0|The Atlantic Ocean, 1941.  German U-boats are struggling to maintain mastery over the sea, challenged everywhere they turn by the British Navy.  Increasing numbers of German vessels are being lost and manpower is running short.  The Nazi government has resorted to sending callow young seamen out on missions that are steadily growing more dangerous.  Welcome to the world of Das Boot. <br /> <br />Beautiful camera work and poignant dialogue draw you into the world of the captain and crew. You share with them the boredom of non-combat operations, the thrill of the chase, and the terror of a depth charge laden destroyer passing overhead.   <br /> <br />Das Boot goes to great lengths to make you forget that the crew are Nazis, instead focusing on the human aspects of the seamen. Change the language as well as a few story elements, and these men could be fighting for any country.  One sees the struggle of the men to understand what it really is that they are fighting for, their anger at being forced into such a dangerous position by a government whose ideologies many of them do not share. <br /> <br />Regardless of whether the crew are Nazis or not, when you hear the telltale ping of a passing destroyer's sonar, and see the abject horror splayed across the faces of these young men, you forget that they are fighting for one of the most despicable governments ever to exist, and instead empathize, feeling every bit of their terror and suspense right along with them. <br /> <br />From beginning to end, Das Boot is an involving film, a must see for every fan of war films. <br /> <br /> <br />
B000A7Q2DM|5.0|Because the truth is that Jared Leto and company have quietly made one of 2005's standout rock albums. As someone who has been hooked on 30 Seconds To Mars since their debut self titled release back in 2002, I can safely safe that \\"A Beautiful Lie\\" is a huge leap forward from the last record (which was great to begin with). 30STM have really come into their own on this release, and as the last record was a broad, atmospheric, spacy and electronic effort in the vein of Tool and Led Zeppelin, \\"A Beautiful Lie\\" is a straightforward rock record with electronic elements. Fans of the afformentioned bands, or of Hard Rock and Alternative will find that this is probably one of the best true rock records to be released this year.    To begin 30STM has a much more focused sound on this record. The songs have been trimmed down to 3 or 4 minute pieces, and in the places where the band would wander or drift off aimlessly in the last album, they stand firm and determined on \\"A Beautiful Lie\\". Jared's voice is just absolutely amazing on this release. It totally overshadows his effort on the self titled. The lead single \\"Attack\\" is a shining example of this. His voice simply carries the song and takes it to new heights when he expands his vocal range. \\"The Kill\\" and \\"The Fantasy\\" are also notable example of Jared's vocal improvements. The guitars continue to work very well together, while not being focused on nu-metal sounding riffs as on the last record. Instead they work together to produce a vintage rock sound that feels perfect for the band. The electronic elements have continued to be incorporated into the band's sound, although they are not as abundant or overwhelming as on the debut. 30STM made a good decision when they decided put their rock elements first and then have their electronics as a background element. This does make the songs carry much more weight instead of pushing the electronics first and have the music come second. Songs like \\"Attack\\" and \\"The Fantasy\\" are obvious rockers, while \\"R-Evolve\\" and \\"A Modern Myth\\" give the album some diversity. The two bonus tracks \\"Battle Of One\\" and \\"Hunter\\" are great additions to the album, although I believe they are available on every album (so that doesn't quite make them bonus tracks). These two tracks should have come before \\"A Modern Myth\\" though; it would have made the album flow better at the end. Overall the album is an excellent listen, especially if you were into the band before this release.     30 Seconds To Mars may not be one of the most publicized bands in the music world today, but they are definitely one of the most talented. \\"A Beautiful Lie\\" is a welcomed addition to the group's discography. Some thought that after their self titled debut, we'd never get anymore music from these guys, but they have returned in true fashion 3 years later. Fans of Hard Rock, Metal, Alternative or just rock in general will find this album offers plenty in every department, and has enough diversity to keep you interested throughout the entire record. My hats goes off to Jared and the guys of 30STM, they have done an excellent job with this release.

B00005JO1J|5.0|WARNING! There are gays, lesbians and cross dressers galore!   There are druggies and slackers and artists quite poor!   There are people with AIDS, if you can handle that fact. One reviewer claimed that the movie had nothing to do with the bohemian movement as they critisized the characters for not wanting to pay rent, insluting the 'yuppie scum' and feeling that they should only focus on there art. Now, I'm a bit confused by this review, who clearly does not approve of such things and also who clearly does not know what bohemian *means.* I'm tired of people who disaprove of the characters actions saying that it doesn't have anyhing to do with bohemia- because it does. They are trying to shoot the movie down in ways that are not accurate or truthful because they do not approve, and that is not in good faith. You want to disapprove- fine. Your disaproval does not make it *not* bohemian. Here is a little info from a website about bohemian lifestyle.    Although the bohemian population was diverse, one particular aspect of how they lived served as a unifying factor: the rejection of bourgeois values. The values they typically rejected and how are as follows:    They rejected private property and materialism by having no permanent residence anywhere and by surviving on little material wealth.   They rejected strict moral values by living carefree lives of alcohol and drug use, as well as open sexual freedom.   They rejected the pursuit of wealth by living solely for art and literature's sake, pursuing their passions regardless of whether they gained an income, which they usually did not.   Members of Bohemia often adopted a communal lifestyle, sharing lodging with other Bohemian companions. They often carried around a few luxury or decorative items that served to spruce up a drab living space for a night of celebration.  The bohemian life was carefree. As part of their rebellion against \\"genteel\\" society, bohemians felt no reason to exhibit moral or socially acceptable behavior. One participant, Houssaye, printed in his memoirs, \\"We were afraid of nothing and thumbed our noses at public opinion. . .The most outstanding characteristic of our Bohemian existence was our open revolt against all prejudices, I might say against all laws. We lived as if entrenched in a fortress from which we made belligerent sallies ridiculing everything.\\"  Bohemians tended to indulge in alcohol as well as drug experimentation. In fact, drugs were used by many to supposedly help with inspiration. Bohemians were also overtly promiscuous, in contrast to how the bourgeois obscured this facet of their lives.   In contrast to the Bourgeois preoccupation with obtaining wealth and status, the bohemian life was characteristically idle; idle in the sense that they did nothing that yielded material wealth. A friend of Houssaye said, \\"I don't do any work, on the pretext of writing a poem; and I write a poem to have an excuse for not doing anything.\\"   Bohemians felt the need to express and assert themselves, being at such a social and economic disadvantage. It was almost as if they flaunted their marginality; by practicing an alternative and contrasting lifestyle, bohemians undermined the bourgeois.   [...]t/hist255-s01/boheme/lifestyle.html

0140187650|5.0|Eichmann in Jerusalem is one of those few books concerning the Holocaust that offers both the historical authenticity of primary texts and analytical perspective of secondary sources. The actual trial itself is, as Arendt has written, surprising in the banality of the defendent, and yet ever more chilling because of it. Arendt herself is an arcute observer and her reflections during the trial offer fresh insights into the mindset of the perpertuators even now. While many of the Holocaust books offer intimidate details on events, few dwelve into the minds of the 'villains' the way Arendt has. I highly recommend this invaluable book, not just for studies of Holocaust, but for anyone who is interested in how the human mind works, and how typical assessment of the these situations fail to account for psychology.

0684824906|5.0|Of the year's history books, I'd rank Team of Rivals at the very top, above even David McCullough's fine 1776.  At once a group biography and a history of the Civil War and the years leading up to it, this book is a true achievement. <br /> <br />Using the lives -- sometimes separate, sometimes intertwined -- of Abraham Lincoln, William Seward, Salmon Chase, and Edward Bates, Goodwin takes the reader into the tumultuous world of American politics in the 1830s, 1840s, and 1850s as slavery increasingly came to dominate the national (and sectional-state-local, for that matter) debate.  Goodwin tells the stories of the rivals in the years before their careers intersected and does so in a way in which no detail, no anecdote, seems out of place.  Everything seems relevant, either to getting an idea of the personalities of these men or to following the history of the period.  Through these individual biographies, Goodwin allows the slavery debate to unfold.  This section is brilliantly constructed. <br /> <br />While the first part is more biographical, the rest of the book chronicles the unfolding of the Civil War, militarily and especially politically, and the role these rivals -- and a few others, including Edwin Stanton -- played in running the war.  The details of the war itself are fairly well known, and Goodwin doesn't break any new ground there.  However, she presents these events through the lens of the friendships and rivalries within the Cabinet.  It is a revealing -- as well as fascinating -- approach.  In the mind of the reader, as well as of men like Seward, Lincoln emerges as the best of the bunch, magnanimous in victory and gracious in defeat, a master of the day-to-day give-and-take of politics. <br /> <br />I'll repeat a minor complaint I've heard voiced before:  next to Lincoln, Seward, and Chase, Edward Bates seems not to warrant the extensive treatment he receives in the book.  Except for the fact that he was considered for the 1860 presidential nomination (and one can debate how seriously that consideration was in the first place), his accomplishments and reputation do not match the others'.  Far more deserving of the fourth slot -- and far more exemplary of the \\"rival\\" label -- is Edwin Stanton, despite the fact that he was not in the running for the nomination. <br /> <br />But this is a small point in a book so large, so interesting, so well-done.  Team of Rivals is sure to become a classic.
B00005JOFO|5.0|Brokeback Mountain is a love story that cuts across lines of gender and sexuality, gripping the viewer with a dreadful sorrow that the deep and passionate devotion that these two lovers feel for each other is forbidden to them, on sentence of death. I cannot imagine how anyone but the most hard-hearted and bigoted of viewers could fail to see that the lovers portrayed in Brokeback Mountain are not different from us--whether we be gay or straight, male or female, rural or urban, we are all capable of loving the same way. Their tragedy is simply that society was and is incapable of accepting them. But most of all, above and beyond its controversial topic, Brokeback Mountain is one of the finest examples of filmmaking I've ever seen. I will make a point of seeing it again before it leaves the theaters.

B000BW7QWW|5.0|PLUMB CRAZY: What's happened to me? My entire life, I've never ever been this enamored of a film. It's like catchin' a serious case of the Beatlemania. Never fear: `Serenity' has arrived.  <br /> <br />HOT AS A WHOREHOUSE ON NICKEL NIGHT: Terrific dialogue rendered in a wickedly engaging lexical mixture of American West / Mandarin / semi-antiquated English. Hi-larious repartee. Strongly delineated characters that (gulp!) actually drive the plot rather than the innocuously interchangeable folk we see in today's tv/film. Unique future worlds where the only aliens are the people who inhabit them. A frontier-style existence butting heads with the 26th century. And that's just the beginning. `Serenity' is a rodeo ride of adrenal action, bucking emotional intensity, jolting plot-twists (ok, enough metaphor.) Oh! I can't forget the stirring score by David Newman. Haunting musical motives for the ship as well as for its captain, passengers and enigmatic foe.  Did I mention absolutely perfect casting? Can't imagine anyone else in these roles. (And yes, I've ordered multiple copies of Serenity - a most excellent Christmas gift for the deserving.) <br /> <br />POWERFUL GOOD: Once upon a time, my housemate forced me to view a single downloaded episode of this movie's tv series precursor: `Firefly.' Bang! I was hooked. This little bit of illegality paid off in spades for the network beancounters; I went on to purchase 4 dvd sets of the tv series. (One is going to my local library. Share the wealth!) <br /> <br />Having said how enthralled I became with the show, I'm way too close to these great characters and their world to ever step back and judge impartially. So I can't really attest to the `standalone-ness' of `Serenity' for newbies.  <br /> <br />However - some anecdotal evidence says it's a great introduction to this wonderful world of writer/director Joss Whedon: I took an uninitiated friend to the Boston `Serenity' opening. By her demand, I loaned the Firefly discs one by one. Within 5 days, she was phoning me, \\"Ok! I'm ready for the next disc!\\" \\"Uh... sorry, those 14 episodes- that's all there is.\\" \\"WHAT? YOU'RE KIDDING! WHAT AM I GONNA DO?\\" (See Serenity again, naturally!) Now, with her own Firefly dvd set permanently occupying the player, she's begun filming a documentary focusing on Firefly/Serenity's New England fans.  <br /> <br />FINE AS CREAM GRAVY: One last thing - for me, frustratingly irresolute Anti-heroes and downright congenial Villains never fail to create that delectably mysterious `grey' area so reflective of our actual lives. Thanks for the inspiration Joss!
0553801503|5.0|Wow, after reading some of the negative reviews of this book (let's call it book number 4A), I was a bit worried. But a needless worry, there is little discernable lettup of quality in this book from the first 3. To be sure, there are not quite the number of seismic events within the timeframe (I'm guessing about 8 months) written about in \\"A Feast for Crows\\", but rest assured, there are NOT very many new characters introduced (other than the obligitory references to scores of relationships and relatives!); and the plot is not meandering at all. A Feast for Crows largely tells tales of minor skirmishes and political intrigue that follow the extensive wars that comprised the second and third books. Perhaps the nay-sayers simply are not impressed when there isn't a steady diet of death and destruction or nonstop action?<br /><br />Martin keeps the focus over the story's timeframe to 6 major characters: Brienne, Jaime, Cersie, Sansa, Arya and Samwell; introduces a few characters to flesh out the political climate of the southern land of Dorne (curious about the Red Viper's home?) and describes the ongoing saga of the Ironborn as they seek to infiltrate their way into the mainland.<br /><br />It seems to me that this is a plenty big, but scarcely new, canvas of storylines to keep track of. I appreciated the limited scope of the book to these storylines; many times as I read the first three books, I would skip several story lines to follow the evolution of one or two of the characters before going back again. This is a perfectly logical approach to the story telling as there is very little physical interaction between the characters in this book versus those to come in the next. Martin's choice to segregate the 4th book into books 4A and 4B isn't the least bit distracting if you can put the other characters on hold in your mind (which you have to do in any book, just for not quite as long a period of time).<br /><br />Within the six major characters storylines, we get (amoungst other things):<br /> - An update on the doings of the Westro's most clever (and extremely honorable, in his own way) player, Littlefinger as Sansa's \\"father\\". As with most of Martin's characters, Petyr Baelish comes in various shades of grey; readers are afforded a chance to draw their own conclusions as to just how grey...<br /> - A momentary look at Catelyn revived (for better or worse!) in Brienne's story<br /> - A momentary look at Jon who sends Sam and Maester Aemon on a mission<br /> - The releationship of Cersei's son and daughter-in-law; and the administration for the Iron Throne done Cersei's way<br /><br />Several storylines are making a direct beeline for Dany, and it's too early to tell where Brienne will end, so I think it pre-mature to criticize the editing until more has played out. Thus far, I haven't seen any storyline drift into irrelevance so I have no reason to not be optimistic...<br /><br />As for those who liken this release to the crumbled messes that became Jordan's WOT (somewhat revived in KoD), or to a lesser degree Goodkind's SOT, give it a rest! Complain all you want about the lack of action, but the details and pace (reasonably fast for my tastes) of the story are well justified for those readers who are curious about characters and cultures of all of the major kingdoms and how they are reacting to the events of their time. There are no endless fussings over fashions, no endless repetitions of mannerisms, no 200 pages to cover the day in the life of one character (apparently there are those who actually like such ramblings in the WOT world?), no endlessly immature characterizations, no repetative philisophical oratories; the focus remains mainly on the fully adult characters or the evolution of the younger characters that we already know and how they are coping with the aftermath of the preceding books. The few new characters introduced by Martin are reasonably described according to the depth of their impact on the story.<br /><br />My only minor quibble with the book is that for the first time we end with a couple of cliffhangers of an immediate kind; prior to this book, Martin did a pretty good job of leaving off at places that were intriguing, but not in the middle of a life and death situation. Hopefully, these will be resolved as part of Book 4B -- I think it's a bit unreasonable to have to wait for more than a year to see whether or not a couple of the specific main characters live or die.<br /><br />In summary, if you enjoy the way Martin has richly developed his characters and story, and don't mind the reality that most people DON'T change that much (except, of course, for the younger characters who are evolving in ways that might surprise), and don't mind that you'll have to wait until next year to read about Danys, Jon, Tyrion and Stannis, amoungst others, you'll find much to deeply appreciate in this effort.st time we end with a couple of cliffhangers of an immediate kind; prior to this book, Martin did a pretty good job of leaving off at places that were intriguing, but not in the middle of a life and death situation. Hopefully, these will be resolved as part of Book 4B -- I think it's a bit unreasonable to have to wait for more than a year to see whether or not a couple of the specific main characters live or die.    In summary, if you enjoy the way Martin has richly developed his characters and story, and don't mind the reality that most people DON'T change that much (except, of course, for the younger characters who are evolving in ways that might surprise), and don't mind that you'll have to wait until next year to read about Danys, Jon, Tyrion and Stannis, amoungst others, you'll find much to deeply appreciate in this effort.

Only time will tell if they are one of the greats, or merely a very good band of this decade. One thing seems clear, though, and that's that they're only getting better. So, I say, do believe the hype and check out Franz Ferdinand.

Other songs here are fine. For example, No More No More has that kind of Rolling Stones boogie sound that Aerosmith do very well. Round and Round is very heavy, and kind of anticipates ths early 90s grunge era (a link one can hear through later bands like Die Kreuzen, Mother Love Bone, Alice in Chains, Screaming Trees, etc). You See Me Crying is what a power ballad should be. And their delivery of the cover song here, Big Ten Inch Record, is still funny, albeit it an adolescent sort of way.Kudos also to the solid, non flashy rhythm section of Joey Kramer and Tom Hamilton for their playing throughout.<br /><br />It's no wonder that Aerosmith were so beloved, by Wayne and Garth, by the characters in the film Dazed and Confused, and by the kids in my high school and neigborhood, not to mention by me. Listening to this 70s hard rock classic brings out my inner 15 year old.o beloved, by Wayne and Garth, by the characters in the film Dazed and Confused, and by the kids in my high school and neigborhood, not to mention by me. Thus, execution - the ability to get things done, particularly on a strategic level - has become the sine qua non of management science. Authors Larry Bossidy and Ram Charan observe that some people grow when promoted to executive leadership, while others merely swell. Those who lose touch with the operational realities of their businesses soon find themselves boldly leading a company going nowhere. The practical value of achieving objectives and getting things done must be instilled at every level of your company, and injected into the very DNA of your corporate culture. Anything less, and your company will under perform. Bossidy and Charan have sterling credentials when it comes to getting things done for America's leading corporations. They say execution is nothing more than faithfully practicing the right techniques with a disciplined approach. B00005JNEI|4.0|I will never forget the first time I saw Michael Moore's anger-provoking film, Fahrenheit 9-11. It was June 2004, and I was sitting in a jam-packed theater in ultra-conservative Lancaster, PA. I went to see the movie with a buddy of mine, and the two of us were the only non-right wingers in the theater. We were also only two of a handful of people under the age of retirement in the theater as well. What my friend and I thought was well-placed sarcasm and humor, the right wing Republicans thought was anti-American, biased, Bush bashing. I remember laughing hysterically at certain points of the film...only to encounter the look of death from countless white, right-wing extremists who were dead-set on their blind patriotism. Upon leaving the theater, the real fun began as heated arguments escalated between spectators as they exited.    Regardless of your personal politics, or your thoughts on Iraq, or your thoughts on Michael Moore, the record needs to be set straight on a few things. Does Moore promote a particular agenda in this film? Yes, of course he does...as does Bush, Cheney, Rice, and Rumsfeld every single time they get in front of a TV camera for one of their photo-ops. Does Moore distort certain facts and stack the cards to favor his particular point of view? Yes, of course he does...as does Bush, Cheney, Rice, and Rumsfeld every single time they get in front of a TV camera for one of their photo-ops. Wouldn't it be nice if those mindless sheep (Republicans) who scream bloody murder over Moore's \\"factual inaccuracies\\" in F-911 would get equally heated and steamed everytime Bush or Cheney or Rumsfeld spout lies to the American people about war or weapons of mass destruction?    Those who oppose this movie have a particular agenda of their own...they want to stifle any and all opposition to the current militaristic, \\"my country right or wrong\\" philosophy that has an iron grip on this nation. To them, a free press and freedom of thought and speech is \\"dangerous\\"and \\"unpatriotic\\" and aids and abets \\"terrorists.\\"  What a joke!    Now...to the film itself. I have always liked the fact that Michael Moore dares to ask the tough questions to the people who most need to be asked them. However...Moore goes one step further and catches them on tape. Remember in Bowling for Columbine when Moore confronted Dick Clark and Charlton Heston over welfare-to-work policies and gun issues? Moore offers us another dose in F-911 when he camps out on the U.S. Capitol Building trying to encourage Congressmen to send their sons and daughters into the military to fight in Iraq. Their Congressmen's silence is deafening.    Moore employs plenty of his smart-alecky, sarcastic humor in Fahrenheit 9-11 to underscore several points: Bush's secret financial relationship with the Saudis, America's historic partnerships with Iraq and Bin Laden, the Bush Administration's botched response to the 9-11 Commission, the ridiculous \\"Coalition of the Willing\\" nonsense, the Patriot Act's true intentions, and the invasion of Iraq as a decoy and diversion.    As with all of Moore's films, Fahrenheit 9-11 mixes drama with satire, humor with gripping seriousness. The most poignant parts of the film deal with 9-11 survivors and their relatives and also the relatives of soldiers killed in Iraq. These scenes are almost too painful to watch.    F-911 has some fairly violent and distrubing images, however. One scene shows footage of a public decapitation in Saudi Arabia, and there are several other scenes that depict images of innocent civilians injured and maimed or even killed in the current Iraq war.     The only part of 9-11 that I thought should have been left out was the first 10 minutes of the film when Moore recounts the Bush presidency from Election Day 2000 up until September 10, 2001. It is clear that this was intended to smear and humiliate Bush, and served no overall meaningful purpose in critiquing Bush's policies post-911.    Overall, if you are open-mindedand want to explore the current situation in Iraq from a different angle than the everyday spin you get on Fox News, then this film is definitely worth checking out. The DVD is packed with plenty of nice extras, including footage on the release of F-911 and the notoriety it garnered. There is also a great extra on Arab American comedians and how they have incorporated the post-911 backlash against Arabs into their routines. Other extras include footage of Condoleeza Rice's cherade in front of the 9/11 Commission and Bush's press conference spin following his private meeting with the 9/11 Commission, along with a segment on Abu Ghraib and the handling of prisoners by Army personnel.     Freedom of speech is a wonderful thing, isn't it?

0553801503|1.0|First let me say that I have been an enthralled reader of George R.R. Martin's \\"A Song Of Ice And Fire\\" series.  I think the first three novels are among the best in the fantasy category.  IMHO, they outrank almost everything except Tolkien and C.S. Lewis.  I have been eagerly awaiting the next volume in the series ever since I finished reading  \\"A Storm of Swords\\" just days after it was published. <br /> <br />I'm very sorry, therefore, to have to say that \\"A Feast For Crows\\" is a huge disappointment.  In a nutshell, George Martin has caught \\"Robert Jordan Disease.\\"  This book loses the reader in a boring, threadless maze of little vignettes mostly devoted to two-dimensional, minor characters.  Most of the major characters are missing----and Martin's explanation that this is because he \\"had\\" to break what he had written into two volumes due to length just doesn't hold water.  The plot is lost.  Character development is mostly absent.  The writing is perfunctory at best.  I didn't come even close to finding myself on the edge of my chair in the way I did with virtually every page of the previous volumes.  <br /> <br />Martin says he is finishing the story for some characters in this book, and will finish for the others in the next--a big error, IMHO.  Assuming two books were really necessary, far greater interest would have been generated by moving the entire story part way along in one volume and finishing it all in the next.  It's more likely, however, that what was really needed was much better editing, resulting in a single, large volume at the same level of quality on display in the earlier books. <br /> <br />At a minimum, I would recommend saving your money now, waiting to buy this book more cheaply in paperback, and reading it only when the promised additional volume comes out.  I fear, though, that unless the writing in the next book is dramatically improved, the promise of the first three volumes may remain unfulfilled.

B000BMSTMS|4.0|Korn has proven that they have staying power and can outlast their imitators. Korn's many copycats once plagued the nu-metal scene but have now gone extinct, and Korn had a hand in inventing rap-metal but then left that genre behind like the dead dog it is.  They're still around because they continue to look forward and stretch the limits of their sound. After the loss of founding guitarist Head (I wonder if his \\"conversion\\" is going to stick), remaining guitarist Munky wisely decided not to cheat by doubling up multiple guitar parts in the studio. Munky's more sparse sound here is actually an interesting development for Korn, bringing stronger songwriting to the forefront.  Also, Fieldy now has room to get more subtle and nimble on bass, not relying so much on his traditional madcap slapping.<br /><br />The missing extra guitar has been effectively replaced by experiments in industrial and electronica, with general over-production from The Matrix. In some ways, these new sounds offer a strong new direction for Korn, but in other ways there are signs that they have turned down a dead-end road. The songs that most benefit from the new approach are the powerful \\"Hypocrites,\\" which is the album's strongest track, and the ambitious \\"Open Up,\\" which truly sounds like nothing else in Korn's history. But on the other hand, the electronics are a real problem for tracks like the awful \\"Throw Me Away\\" and the cluttered \\"Love Song,\\" which sound like the typical industrial deathmarches that were being churned out by Nine Inch Nails (or even worse, Filter) a decade ago. Not to mention, the synthesized beats detract attention from the always-improving David Silveria (one of the most criminally under-appreciated drummers in rock).<br /><br />Unfortunately, simply adding synth squiggles and noisy fake beats to the existing Korn sound is not really progress, but clutter, and I'd be surprised if they can do much more with this new direction on future albums. But in the end, there is an even more important improvement on this album, and that concerns Jonathan Davis. Like the band itself, Jonathan has buried the army of imitators who once tried to latch onto the manic-depressive goth-metal vocal style that he mostly created himself, and he continues to expand his emotional range (the best example here is the surprisingly effective power ballad \\"Tearjerker\\"). And Jonathan has finally &#8211; FINALLY &#8211; expanded his lyrics beyond his typical griping about his lousy childhood, tackling a great many personal and social issues on this album with real depth and exploration. 0393324818|5.0|Michael Lewis' interest covering outliers (trailblazers later) brings him to the land of baseball, where the old guard is well entrenched and the barriers to entry of new philosophies high.    In the middle of it all is the Oakland A's manager Billy Beane, the strongest proponent of statistics-based evaluation of players (a.k.a \\"Moneyball\\"). Ironically, Beane's baseball career is Exhibit A of the foibles of the \\"if it stands like a ball player, looks like a ball player then it is a baseball player\\" school of baseball thought.    The central theme of this book is not at all new as Bill James published his theories of sabermetrics way back in 1977. However, this has only been recently been put to practice not only by the A's but the Dodgers (ex-GM Paul de Podesta), Blue Jays (JP Ricciardi) - Beane disciplies all.    The theory is quite interesting as it attempts not to reverse but to extend current baseball thought. ERA for instance, long held as the metric for which pitchers are judged, is not that accurate as it may be padded by inherited runs. A more apt metric is the no. of home runs, strikeouts and walks (not hits) - stats that a pitcher has direct control over. The book provides quite a convincing argument as to why the no. of hits given up by the pitcher are not influenced by factors other than, get this - LUCK!    Batters on the other hand should be judged by one stat alone - On Base Percentage (OBP). The book provides a good argument as to why steals, sacrifice bunts and flies are anathema to winning baseball.    All in all, Billy Beane's practices do end up making winning teams out of a limited budget but up to a certain extent only as former diamonds in the rough tend to command large free agent contracts thereafter and the GM has to rebuild from scratch. I'd characterize it more as the art of treading water with a limited budget as it still needs a large financial commitment from the ownership to create dynasties.     It would be interesting to see the Yankees employ Moneyball for the moneyed. Still, if all of baseball would finally get it then we're back to square one - being that money-laden teams having the advantage.

B00005JO04|3.0|Ambitious statement from writer-director Stephen Gaghan (Traffic) about the ongoing clash between America's oil companies and the Middle East. Gaghan's film incorporates multiple story lines which he is only barely able to hold together in his portrait of what is now called \\"The Clash of Civilizations,\\" but the film's incoherence may in fact be its strength, as Gaghan correctly refuses to provide simple answers about the oil companies, the US government, and Islamic fundamentalism. He forces the viewer to immerse himself in a chaotic realm, a realm of greed, betrayal, and conflicting values. George Clooney gives probably his most likeable performance to date as Bob Barnes, a CIA operative in Beirut who is captured and tortured, and then sold out by the government. Matt Damon is also good as a corporate analyst determined to make a splash off of a family tragedy with a Gulf prince, and Jeffrey Wright plays a corporate lawyer trying to aid the merger of two major oil companies. All of the acting is solid, and the footage of the Middle East is quite beautiful, yet it evokes the danger and uncertainty of the region. Syriana unfortunately suffers from largely poor and amateurish directing (Gaghan's first attempt at filming his script), employing I suppose a cinema verite mode of shaky cam, trying to recapture the feel of a documentary, but its only comes across as contrived and self-aggrandizing. Syriana is a triumph of content not form, and it is probably the most provocative and important Hollywood movie of the year.

B00006RINF|2.0|To the unitiated, Italian rock/metal outfit Lacuna Coil might sound like they're cashing in on the \\"dark rock\\" trend set by American whinge-rock pioneers Evanescence, even though Lacuna Coil have been doing their thing years before Amy Lee and Evanescence decide to start whining-, I mean singing. <br /> <br />Unfortunately, Lacuna Coil suffer from the same flaw that Evanescence does: a talented singer stuck with a mediocre band. Musically, \\"Comalies\\" is mostly bereft of any creativity, and seems aimed directly into the midst of the mainstream. As a result, most tracks come of as being repetitive, unimaginative, and worst of all, just plain boring. <br /> <br />Whether or not this band can be considered \\"metal\\" is up for debate. There's nary a riff to be found, and the guitars lack any aggressiveness or bite; they're just there as if by force of habit. The drumming is incredibly simplistic; there are no fills or any creativity behind the kit at all. The bland noises generated by the guitars and drums would be befitting of some horrid nu-metal band, except that Lacuna Coil decided throw a healthy (and by healthy I mean WAY too much) dose of keyboard effects into the mix. This horrid batch of synthesized defecation absolutely ruins the experience; keyboards are best used in a subtle manner, yet Lacuna Coil throws them about over nearly every track. I don't know if this was to cover up their lack of musical talent, but their overuse drags down the album as a whole. <br /> <br />The track sequencing is suspect as well. The two best tracks, \\"Swamped\\" and \\"Heaven's a Lie\\" are placed right at the beginning. This promises the unsuspecting listener more of the same, but \\"Comalies\\" quickly descends into an empty spiral (ahahahaha) of mediocrity and boredom from which it never recovers. It displays the disturbing trend of mainstream albums to throw on one or two \\"singles\\" on the album and leave the rest as pure filler. <br /> <br />And while Cristina Scabbia might be a good vocalist, the band simply relegates her to mere eye candy and doesn't let her sing enough. But maybe I'm biased in this regard, because there's another singer, Andrea Ferro, who apparently took his inspiration from Chester Bennington. His loud wailings are indescribably horrible; if you thought Tuomas singing on Nightwish's debut \\"Angels Fall First\\" was bad and detracted from the music, wait until you hear this! The best parts of \\"Comalies\\" are where Ferro keeps his mouth shut. <br /> <br />I cannot honestly recommend this album, and any self-described metalhead would do best to stay away from it, as it is more Power Pop than metal. Lacuna Coil is just another band whose desire for mainstream success robbed them of their creativity. Pass on this one.

Hilarious. This book will keep you thinking for a long timed afterward.

This would make half of a great concept album all by itself. Can you say Echoes II? Let's hope.

0553801503|2.0|I will start this review by  stating that the previous three books by Martin are among the very best books I have ever read. That being said I believe that the love for the other books kept me reading on in this one. Whereas I could not put down the other three books, I had to force myself to read thorugh some of the chapters in this book. I was really disappointed in A Feast for Crows.  <br /> <br />First I was disappointed in the lack of content on the existing characters that we have grown to love. There is little development on the Stark daughters and no content on Dany or Tyrion (although we are promised that on book 5). Jon Snow and the Wall and left out of this book as well. The focus of the book is on Kings Landing, however Cersei and Jaime are really the only main characters to write about. The chapters on them are what continued to drive me to read. The chapters on Brienne the Boring were tedious at best. I do not why Martin decided to add Brienne's traveling to the main story line. Alot of time in this book was spent on detailing the travel of the characters over long distances with no real development. Some of these chapters could be cut out and the reader or the book would suffer none.  <br /> <br />Another problem I had with this book is its lack of real content. The book is almost 700 pages and has only one real plot twist at the end. One thing that I had come to love is the plot twists in all of Martin's preceding books. Martin's unpredictability ensured that you did not know what was going to happen next. This book was also missing that element.  This book seemed to only set up the future stroy lines. I can only hope that book 5 is not the same way for ther other characters. It also introduces too many Sers and lords that have no bearing on the story line but only make thebook thicker. Martin had much of the same in the other books but somehow it seemed so much more tedious in this book.   <br /> <br />I have been anticipating this book I soon as Iclosed A Storm of Swords. A Feast for Crows falls short of the standards Martin has set for this series. To be fair the book carried lofty expectations following the previous installments. After I finished this book it really left a bad taste in my mouth. My biggest fear is that Martin will become another one of those authors that begins a brilliant tale but is unable to finish (i.e. Robert Jordan). If so the next books could be much of the same. That would be a shame. I can only hope that the future books are able to recapture the same kind of magic the first three books possessed.

0061015725|4.0|This book is certainly one of the best works Crichton has come out with. There are a number of things which make Prey an interesting read, by and large this book offers both the sci-fi enthusiast as well as the average suspense reader to partake in its excitement!<br /><br />The story follows the main character Jack around as he slowly but surely winds up in a life or death struggle with high technology. The beginning of this book is perhaps the most engaging aspect as we're introduced to a main character that is a stay at home dad as well as an all around nice guy. His wife, on the contrary, is a heavy weight corporate type that never spends anytime with the children and somehow manages to keep her relationship with her husband going throughout the years. This doesn't last... not exactly.<br /><br />From the very beginning of the book the two core characters - Jack and his wife - are pitted against one another as Jack begins to suspect his wife of having an affair. Little does he know that what is also going on is that the high tech company she works for (using a technology he created), is releasing a highly technological toxin into the atmosphere. Jack is mysteriously brought into the situation, unaware and completely unprepared for the events that transpire throughout the novel.<br /><br />Without going into too much detail it should be noted that this novel is more detailed than your average suspense/action book, and yet at times Crichton gets ahead of himself and manages for a few paragraphs to go on and on about either a technology he himself created for the book, or a technology with is merely theorized about in the real world (this can be slightly distracting for those that aren't used to Michael Crichton's works). It is true when many reviewers have said this book is a real page turner, you're bound to get so hooked that you'll spend an entire night just trying to finish it!<br /><br />Prey is not without flaws however, one annoying thing about the book is that the action sequences seemed a bit rushed. Not only that but the way in which the nanotechnology operates at times (and fights back) seems a bit, well, too human... more importantly, it seems a bit foolish. Crichton often mentions how these barbaric ways of fighting are \\"efficient\\" for killing purposes, and yet even by man's standards they simply are not (body slamming and choking comes to mind from the novel). It truly seems as though Crichton rushed to put all of his great ideas on paper without actually considering how interesting he made (or failed to make) them sound.<br /><br />Another fault with the book has also been mentioned in the past: with the exception of the main character most of the characters in the book seem rather flat. This is of course not without reason, as Crichton introduces a myriad of characters and it would have taken him far longer to go into detailed accounts as to each of their histories and personalities, yet I would have liked to have read that. Yet given the novel was a classic action/suspense read, this is easily forgivable.<br /><br />I'm giving this book a 4.5/5 for its great story, plot, and action scenes - a true page turner as I previously stated, and yet I felt there was something missing on the description end of it as far as the characters were concerned. I'm also inclined to feel as though the ending was a bit rushed. Regardless, a great read!book is that the action sequences seemed a bit rushed. My friend has a decent sound system hooked up to his DVD player and television and still we were straining to hear it. The problem with the audio doesn't end there though; the dialogue itself is what you'd expect from a modern day spy comedy... just downright idiotic. Based on the dialogue alone the movie was obviously made simply to give nods to Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt.<br /><br />Well so the film is just one of those actor-fan-flock type movies, how about the actual story? It wasn't terrible it could have been presented much better though. You have two assassins that are married that are under the assumption that their spouse has a relatively normal job. The problem occurs when we're given silly scenarios such as Angelina Jolie coming home and changing from a dominatrix outfit beside Brad Pitt, and Brad Pitt seemingly not noticing simply because he's a few feet away. Doesn't he know she owns that kind of clothing? Are we to take it for granted that he questions her loyalty in the relationship merely because they are seeing a marriage councilor?<br /><br />I suppose if you like Mr. No Personality Brad Pitt then you won't mind his character, who like him has absolutely no personality (I don't mean to disrespect Brad Pitt entirely, he's been in some wonderful films but as of late he seems to be developing amnesia because he keeps forgetting that his characters should have /some/ personality). As for Angelina Jolie? Absolutely stunning as always, flashing smiles, big round lips... well, that's exactly what you got here, no other character personality traits can be described because there are none to mention!<br /><br />I suppose in the end what matters is whether or not this comedy delivers both from as a decent action film as well as a comedy. The cinematographers and artistic designers must have been hard at work, because admittedly the sets were very pretty (and that's all that could be said about them), but that alone doesn't carry a movie - the action sequences were absurd, too fast, without justification, and probably required no more than half a second worth of movement on the part of the actors.<br /><br />The comedy in the movie is what got me really upset though... what exactly was so enjoyable about anything the characters did or said? The fact that Angelina has her weapons inside the kitchen sink, is that supposed to be laugh-out-loud-funny? Is it funny that she is whipping a masochist, playing the S&M bit while trying to obtain information from him right before she assassinates him? That isn't the least bit humorous to me. The lines in this movie are not witty, cute, or funny... at the very least they are insulting to the average intelligent viewer. If you find Angelina Jolie wearing sexy clothing to be sexy, as many people do, then you'll undoubtedly find this movie \\"sexy.\\" If like me you think \\"sexy\\" in a movie refers to an intellectual sort of lustily appeal, than you will no doubt find these comments to be ridiculous, maybe in the 70s and 60s they were stylish and sexy but in a movie like this they just come across as pathetic.<br /><br />Of course this review is going to generate a lot of \\"Not Helpful\\" remarks simply because people disagree with me, not because they actually find my opinion helpful or not (a common practice on Amazon when you disagree with someone, silence out the opposition). 038533348X|2.0|Cat's Cradle has little to offer but Kurt Vonnegut's very pessimistic assessment of religion, politics, and love.  The characters are just \\"types,\\" and so incompletely sketched that we can't care what happens to any of them.  The plot brings together an assortment of these characters - for no apparent reason at all - to an island for a doomsday scenario.  After the scenario plays out, we receive from Vonnegut the valuable intelligence that all of mankind's effort is meaningless and absurd, and that the best we can hope for is a good laugh at the joke that God has played on us.  Most readers will have no reason to trouble with this inconsequential work.

0553801503|2.0|I am sorry to give this book a poor review.  I LOVED the previous three books, five stars each, but this book does not live up to expectation.<br /><br />The many criticisms you've heard about the book's disjointed nature are true.  I keenly felt the absence of prior characters.  In addition, the author's difficulty in writing the book comes through.<br /><br />It took Martin more than five years to write this book, and it's obvious to me.  He doesn't know where he wants to take us. I was often struck by how I had to press on - which was a sharp contrast with the prior volumes where sleep was a nuisance since it kept me from reading.<br /><br />The kindest thing that I can say about many of the chapters of this volume is that they may be necessary to get to where the author ultimately wants to take us, and though tedious, are a necessary evil.  The worst that I can say is that the author may be milking the story for money.<br /><br />By way of explanation for the redacted version of the story, Martin writes, \\"I felt that the readers would be better served by a book that told all the story for half the characters, rather than half the story for all the characters.\\"  He further consoles that \\"there's more to come. [We can expect a]nother book as big as this one.\\"  That's cold comfort to me since this was the shortest of the four books.  Furthermore, the idea that book HAD to be split is preposterous.  Lengthy books are published all of the time.  The idea that it is being done for our, the readers, benefit is insulting to our intellect. This book is a money grab.<br /><br />The author and publishers made the conscious decision to double their profits, by splitting the book in two.  I was prepared to give this a pass, but the story suffers for it and the difficulty Martin faces of where to take the story next is exasperated by it.<br /><br />Also, the only characters that appear from the previous history are Arya, Jamie, Sam and Sansa. The rest are new perspectives (though they may not be new characters, e.g., Cersei).  The new perspectives, in large part, are necessary to give the reader an understanding of what is happening in different parts of the realm, but it has the unfortunate effect of bloating a once-concise and riveting series into a meandering mess.  This is not to say that whole series is ruined by FEAST, but that with this addition the series has taken a noticeable departure from what preceded it.<br /><br />All told, this book falls far short of the greatness of the previous three.  I recommend - since you will certainly read it at this point - that you wait for paperback.<br /><br />P.S. - Please Mr. Martin, let's have no more comparisons between how long it took you and how long it took Tolkien to finish his work.  Tolkien's work at least delivered the goods after the wait.  You have compromised your \\"art\\" for money.  Classy.ough they may not be new characters, e.g., Cersei). B000BZISPI|4.0|In some ways, I think I liked the old one better.  While the first version (with Gene Wilder as Wonka) altered and shortened the plot quite a bit, this version -- though it is, in most other respects, wonderfully consistent with the book -- altered Willy Wonka's character.  Roald Dahl depicts Wonka as a slightly eccentric fellow, unfazed by anything, delightfully delighted with his inventions.  The old movie shows Wonka excited about his inventions, though Gene Wilder was a little too old to dance around \\"like a kid at Christmas\\".  In this version, though Johnny Depp was certainly young and spry enough to play Dahl's character perfectly, his script has him mentally disturbed by memories of a terrible childhood at which Roald Dahl never hints.  And the writers, in an attempt to add some \\"family value\\" to a story that has stood quite well as pure fun alone, changed the ending in a way that degraded the quality of the plot.<br /><br />It was still a great movie, and I enjoyed it.  Standing apart from the book, it's fun.  Set alongside it, it's surpassingly admirable.  It is quite rare these days that we find a movie based on a book so incredibly similar in plot to the original work.  However, it's surprising how strong the contrast is between their rigid adherence to Dahl's plot and their extreme reconstruction of Wonka's character.
0393037010|5.0|A recent reviewer pans the Aubrey/Maturin books based on a disappointing and frustrating read of Master and Commander.  I would agree with the reviewer that the issue of nautical terminology is frustrating but that has been solved by several excellent reference works designed specifically to alleviate this issue.   <br /> <br />The reviewers more damning criticism is partially true but ultimately misleading as a criticism of the series.  Master and Commander, the first of the series, is more like a Horatio Hornblower story than a true Aubrey/Maturin novel. It is far more action packed than the remaining books and emphasises naval combat over character development, biological exploration and history. The \\"real\\" beginning of the 20 volume set is Post Captain, the second volume in the series and it is far more characteristic of the series.  O'Brian himself commented that he had not intended to write a series when he did Master and Commander.  His thinking obviously changed before Post Captain was written.  If you are turned off by Master and Commander but like historical novels with a hint of Jane Austin, stay the course and sail on to Post Captain. It is far more subtle and much better written. If you don't like that one then head for land but don't judge the series by the unique first volume.  It's too bad they named the movie after the first volume (even though the movie has nothing to do with the first story) as many folks will start with that atypical book.

I still LOVE the title track... and the more I listen, the more I hear little Queenisms all through the album, though still in general it's a more complete full album than most Queen albums were (as Queen did create ALOT of filler to go with their great songs).  The sound on this album is so classic, it makes you think late 70s and early 80s, but with the crisp clean modern day production.  The mixing is more old-school too... not just all downtuned and uber heavy and more bass filled... they let the guitars shine the most, and more modern mixers need lessons in doing that!  This is just darn catchy hard rock.  The second song, Knockers originally bugged me a bit with the over the top vocals, but I'd say that was only for the first two listens and then I was infected with it singing it around the house in my mind.  Not only do I get used to Justin's voice on repeat listens... it's to the point where I actually really LIKE IT ALOT... mainly because it is so different from anything else out there... it's a nice change of pace... and the production and songs on this album really make the best use of his high voice yet.  In fact, I think it is fair to say this album uses his higher registers much more appropriately within a song than the first one did.  One thing I wish they would improve is the lyrics/subject matter of the songs.  Not that they are bad, in fact they are quite clever... B00005JNTX|3.0|Parts of this film were brilliant, other parts rancid. It's got one of the sharpest looks I've seen in a film in some time. Based on a comic novel, it keeps the depthless surface of its source and used the original material as a storyboard. Miller did the comic, and his codirection credit was a nod to his originality, because the credits say Rodriguez \\"shot and cut\\" the film (i.e., he directed it). The post-noir pornoviolent excess has been likened to \\"Pulp Fiction\\" by Quentin Tarantino, who \\"guest directed\\" one sequence (Rodriguez is his protege; parts of this could be called \\"Kill Bill Three\\"). Its source might be better dated back to Kubrick's \\"A Clockwork Orange\\" (1971), if that film had stayed with strictly storyboarded visuals, drained the Beethoven and color, and stayed with just the pornoviolence. A triptych of three episodes set in the same dystopian alternate world, the film follows the fatalistic misadventures of three antiheroes played by Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke (who got the best reviews), and Clive Owen. Of the three, I liked Owen the best: he had the spaced out look of a comic character, and registered not a single thought behind his eyes. As for whether it's worth seeing, you'll have to decide whether the film's vile, scummy view of humanity is a worthy tradeoff for the startling look at a bizarrely original world.

B000BJS4OY|5.0|Growing up in the 80's, I would constantly hear about how fantastic the \\"Boss\\" was, especially live.  I simply didn't get it. I was absolutely blown away.  This band was so raw, so tight, so passionate.  Here, Bruce is not the bloated weight-lifter guy I remembered, but this scruffy, funky, wiry dude with a knit stocking cap.  His band is similarly young and hungry. Anyone who saw this band live would have been a life-long convert.
